key_insight: Performance loss in end-to-end driving often comes from a mismatch between privileged expert demonstrations and noisy, occluded sensor inputs available to student policies; reducing this learner–expert asymmetry significantly improves closed-loop robustness.
problem_solved: Addresses the gap where imitation-learned driving policies perform well in open-loop evaluation but fail in closed-loop because experts see cleaner, more certain information than the sensor-based student.
method: Quantify and analyze the asymmetry between privileged expert observations and sensor-based learner inputs (visibility, occlusions, uncertainty).
Introduce practical mitigation strategies to close the gap (e.g., degrade or mask expert inputs to match sensors, augment learner observations, and incorporate uncertainty-aware training/losses).
Empirically validate that minimizing this asymmetry yields more robust closed-loop driving in simulation benchmarks.
impact: Makes imitation learning for autonomous driving more reliable by aligning training signals with real sensor conditions — reducing sim-to-real fragility and improving safety and deployability of learned controllers.
visual_elements: Side-by-side visual: expert view (privileged, full visibility) vs. learner view (camera/LiDAR with occlusions) highlighting differences.
Flow diagram of the method pipeline: measure asymmetry → apply alignment strategies (masking/augmentation/uncertainty) → train student → closed-loop evaluation.
Bar/line chart showing closed-loop performance (e.g., success rate, collisions) before vs. after asymmetry reduction across scenarios.
Heatmap or overlay showing uncertainty or visibility regions that cause learner failures and how mitigation reduces them.
paper_title: LEAD: Minimizing Learner-Expert Asymmetry in End-to-End Driving
paper_authors: Long Nguyen, Micha Fauth, Bernhard Jaeger, Daniel Dauner, Maximilian Igl
